message: Hey all -- wanted to throw a note to everyone who helps w/ the Debug Toolbar. Rob and I have decided to take on a more active development stance. We're going to be pushing out versions quicker, and pulling in more community effort
We've started by moving the project to http://github.com/django-debug-toolbar/django-debug-toolbar to give it a more centralized feel

I plan to merge in a bunch of changes I've got stashed in my fork, but I'm hoping to also be able to make some of Disqus' build bots public within the next couple of weeks so everyone can stay up to date on the status of things with it
(my fork includes the first workings of some test cases)

We're planning to start pushing more less-stable code into the master branch, in hopes to make it easier for other forks to keep up to date with code. This should help us roll out some new features much more quickly

@zeeg Sounds really good, I was long wondering what was going on with django-debug-toolbar and your fork of the project. Django-debug-toolbar is already a great tool, a must have but I bet you guys can make it better!
Great! Though I would appreciate a stable version much more than an instable version bloating with features. Will there be releases of stable candidates then?
Brilliant.  Great to get an update.  Cheers :)

@wimfeijen It will likely follow a similar release schedule as to the rest of my apps. That is, there will be major and minor releases. Minor releases will happen more frequently, and will likely just contain small tweaks, features, and bug fixes.
The big difference is the "master" branch (which you shouldn't need to install anyways) will become more of a development branch
@mattg ya just make them against the main repo (under the django-debug-toolbar organization)
to get features in/bugs fixed, should we just make pull requests against the new project page on github?
